title: The teenage esports star who claims Fortnite helped him get his life back
text:
It was an overwhelming feeling, Jake Smith recalls, as the 18-year old from Nottinghamshire took his seat in the elaborate tower of computer terminals at the famous Arthur Ashe Stadium in New York city, ready to compete in front of 20,000 fans for a share of $30m (£24m) at the finals of the Fortnite World Cup.

From the millions of players competing for a spot at the marquee esports event of the phenomenally popular video game, Smith, who goes by the moniker “Smeef” in-game, found himself in the final hundred of the singles tournament. He was set to scrap with 99 other hopefuls in a quest to be the last to survive in a hail of cartoonish gunfire, with the ultimate victor walking away $3m richer.

“On the day I was pretty nervous,” he says. “It was really nice to be there and to see all the seats filling up with people watching us. I wasn’t nervous in the games but beforehand leading up to it I definitely had some butterflies.”

In the event, Smith finished 44th and netted $50,000. However that wasn’t enough for the Mansfield teen who had his sights on loftier goals.

“I wish it went differently,” he says. “I didn’t have the best day. I know 44th in the world out of the millions that played is really good, but it’s not good enough for me. I know I’m better than that, so being labelled as 44th for a year... it hurts, you know what I mean?”
